content:
## 1. First Steps

#### What is computer program?

A program is a list of instructions that are followed one after the other by a computer. You are most likely familliar with lists of instructions in everyday life. An example of a list of instructions would be a cooking recipe:

**Fried eggs**:  

1. heat 2 tablespoons of butter in a non-stick frying pan.
2. break the eggs and slip into pan one at a time.
3. cook until whites are completely set and yolks begin to thicken.
4. carefully flip eggs. cook second side to desired doneness. 
5. sprinkle with salt and pepper. serve immediately.

Another example is this list of instructions on how to put on a life jacket:
![Life jacket](https://www.weheartswift.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/Lifejacket_Instructions-e1433104241751.jpg)

The lists of instructions mentioned above are made to be executed by people. Computer programs are simillarly just lists of instructions but they are meant to be executed by computers. They are meant to be readable and understandable by humans but executing them would often be highly impracticable. 

For example the program used for drawing a single screen in a modern game executes hundred of millions of mathematical operations like additions and multiplications. Executing such a list of instructions would take any person an embarasing amount of time, yet computers can happily do it 60 times per second.

#### Why do we need a programming language?

Lists of instructions like cooking recipes and putting on a life jacket are quite easy to understand for humans but they're incrediblly difficult to understand for a computer. Programming languages are designed as a way of giving a computer instructions that it can easily understand. That is because a programming language (like Swift) is much less ambigous than a language like english. Also it closely resembles the way in which a computer works.

In this book you'll learn the basics of programming using Swift. More importantly this will teach you about the kind of instructions that your computer understands and building programs for it to execute.

Whether you want to build an app, a game or a website the basic principles remain the same. You have to write a program for the computer to execute and writing such a program is done using a programming language.

#### Why Swift?

The Swift programming language was introduced in June 2014 by Apple, since then it has grown immensly in popularity. Swift is primarly used for developing apps and games for the iPhone and the Mac and provides an easier and more enjoyable way of doing that. 

The great news is that Swift is also a great programming language for learning to code because of the **Playgrounds** feature described below.

#### Using Playgrounds

Playgrounds provide a fun and interactive way of writing code. Traditionally you would write a program and run it to see its results. With playgrounds you can see the results of your program imedially as you type it. This gives you a lot of opportunity for experimenting and makes learning faster.

If you have the [companion app for this book](https://www.weheartswift.com/want-to-learn-how-to-code-we-made-an-app-for-that/) than clicking on an exercise will open a playground for you to start coding. 

If you don't have the companion app installed than you can open Xcode and create a new playground by clicking the "Get started with a playground" button. Select OS X As your Platform and choose a destination where you want to save the Playground.

![Create playground](https://www.weheartswift.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/Screen-Shot-2015-02-09-at-7.52.22-PM1.png)

**Note:** If you don't have Xcode installed, download the latest version from [here](https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/xcode/id497799835?mt=12#)

We'll start looking at basic concepts one by one now. We encourage you to experiment with the code we introduce by typing the statements into a playground and changing values around.

#### Variables and Constants

Use the `var` keyword to declare a variable and the `let` keyword to declare a constant. Variables and constants are named values. Variable can change their value over time and constants don't. To change the value of a variable you need to asign it a new one.

```swift
// declares a variable named a that has the value 1
var a = 1 
// assigns the value 2 to the variable a
a = 2
// a has the value 2

// declares a constant named one with the value 1
let one = 1
one = 2 // this gives an error because we cannot change the value of a constant
```
> the text after `//` is called a comment. Comments are ignored by the computer when executing the program. They are usually used to explain parts of code

#### Naming Variables

Variables should usually be named using alphabetical characters. For example: `sum`, `number`, `grade`, `money`

If you want your variable's name to contain multiple words then you should start each word in the name with an uppercase letter except for the first one. For example you want a variable that holds the number of students in a class than you should name it `numberOfStudents` instead of `numberofstudents` because the first  one is more readable.   
This naming convention is called CamelCase.

It's recommanded to use descriptive names for variables. But don't overdo it, for example `numberOfStudents` is a reasonable name while `numberOfStudentsInTheCurrentClass` is too long. A good rule of thumb is to use at most 3 words for the name of a variable.

We could have used a way shorter name for the variable above, for example we could have called it `n`. The disadvantage with short variable names is that they're not expressive. If you read your code after 2 months you most likely won't remember what `n` means. But `numberOfStudents` is immediately obvious.

Generally its not a good idea to have variables that consist of a single letters but there are some exceptions.  
When dealing with numbers that don't represent something it's ok to use single letter names.

#### Basic Operators

You can write arithmetic expressions using numbers, variables, operators and parentheses. 

```swift
// The + operator returns the sum of two numbers
let sum = 1 + 2 // 3

// The - operator returns the difference of two numbers
let diff = 5 - sum // 5 - 3 = 2

// The * operator returns the product of two numbers
let mul = sum * diff // 3 * 2 = 6

// The / operator returns the numbers of times the  divisor(the number on 
// the right side) divides into the dividend(the number on the left side)
// For example, when dividing 6 by 3, the quotient is 2, while 6 is called
// the dividend, and 3 the divisor.
// 13 divided by 5 would be 2 while the remainder would be 3.
let div = mul / diff // 6 / 2 = 3

// The remainder(modulo) operator returns the remainder of the division 
let mod = 7 % 3 // 1 because 7/3 = 2 and remainder 1 (2 * 3 + 1 = 7)

// You can use parentheses to group operations
(1 + 1) * (5 - 2) 

// Multiplication, division and remainder have higher precedence than 
// addition and subtraction.
// For example: 5 + 2 * 3 = 5 + 6 = 11
```

#### Integer Division

Addition, subtraction and multiplication behave pretty much as you expect. The tricky operations are division and remainder.  
Take for example `5 / 2`. Normally you'd expect the result to be `2.5`. In Swift dividing two integers also produces an integer this is acomplished by discarding the part of the number after the decimal point. So `5 / 2 = 2`.  
The remainder operator or modulo operator (%) is used to get the remainder of an integer division. `5 % 2 = 1`  
For `5 / 2`:  
`quotient = 5 / 2 = 2`  
`remainder = 5 % 2 = 1`  
`quotient * 2 + remainder = 5`  

Generally speaking for two integers `a` and `b` this equations always hold  
`quotient = a / b`  
`remainder = a % b`  
`b * quotient + remainder = a`

**NOTICE:** `remainder = a - b * quotient`  
This implies that `remainder = a - b * (a / b)`  and  
`a % b = a - b * (a / b)`  
You can view `a % b` as a shorthand way of computing `a - b * (a / b)`

**NOTICE:** if `a % b = 0` then `b` divides `a`, that is `a` is a multiple of `b`.  
Example:   
`15 / 5 = 3`  
`15 % 5 = 0` ->  
`15 = 5 * 3`

#### Order of statemets and more Playgrounds

The order of statements in a program matters. Like lists of instructions programs are executed from top to bottom.

```swift
var numberOfApples = 7 // you have 7 apples
var numberOfOranges = 2 // you have 2 orages

// you eat an apple (numberOfApples = 6)
numberOfApples = numberOfApples - 1 

// a wizard doubles your oranges (numberOfOranges = 4)
numberOfOranges = numberOfOranges * 2 

var stashedFruits = numberOfApples + numberOfOranges // 10 (6 + 4)

// you receive 2 apples (numberOfApples = 8). stashedFruits remains unchanged!
numberOfApples += 2 

stashedFruits /= 2 // you lose half your stashed fruits 5 (10 / 2)
```

In the program above the variable `stashedFruits` gets a value only after all the previous statements are run. Also notice that the value assigned to a variable is computed at the time of assignment. Changing `numberOfApples` after declaring `stashedFruits` will not have any effect on the value of `stashedFruits`.

Looking at the code above in a playground will give you an idea of why playgrounds are incredibly helpful for visualizing how code behaves.

As you can see each line of code in a playground has the value of the expression on that line printed in the right area of the screen.

![Playground 1](https://www.weheartswift.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/Screen-Shot-2015-02-09-at-8.15.52-PM.png)

Now, the cool thing is that if we modify any values. All lines are imediatelly updated to reflect our changes.
For example we modify:

```swift
var numberOfApples = 25
var numberOfOranges = 30
```

and everything is recalculated and displayed immediately.

![Playground 2](https://www.weheartswift.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/Screen-Shot-2015-02-09-at-8.16.13-PM.png)

Try playing around!

#### Print Statement

After making some computations you will want to show your results somehow. The simplest way to do it is with `print()` statement.  

```swift
// will print Hello Swift! in the console 
// you can print any text between quotes
print("Hello Swift!") 

print(1 + 2) // will print 3

var ten = 10

print(ten) // will print 10
```

To see the console output in Playground make sure to show the `Debug Area`. 

You can do that by pressing the middle button from the top right corner of the Playground.

![](https://www.weheartswift.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/09/Screen-Shot-2015-09-25-at-18.09.091-e1443194066271.png)

Or from the menu:

![](http://www.weheartswift.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/Screen-Shot-2014-12-01-at-17.38.53.png)

This is how the code from the example would look with the `Debug Area` visible:

![](https://www.weheartswift.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/09/Screen-Shot-2015-09-25-at-18.03.41-e1443193694158.png)

If you don't have the companion app installed than you can open Xcode and create a new playground by clicking the "Get started with a playground" button. Select OS X As your Platform and choose a destination where you want to save the Playground.

![Create playground](https://www.weheartswift.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/Screen-Shot-2015-02-09-at-7.52.22-PM1.png)

**Note:** If you don't have Xcode installed, download the latest version from [here](https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/xcode/id497799835?mt=12#)

We'll start looking at basic concepts one by one now. We encourage you to experiment with the code we introduce by typing the statements into a playground and changing values around.

#### Variables and Constants

Use the `var` keyword to declare a variable and the `let` keyword to declare a constant. Variables and constants are named values. Variable can change their value over time and constants don't. To change the value of a variable you need to asign it a new one.

```swift
// declares a variable named a that has the value 1
var a = 1 
// assigns the value 2 to the variable a
a = 2
// a has the value 2

// declares a constant named one with the value 1
let one = 1
one = 2 // this gives an error because we cannot change the value of a constant
```
> the text after `//` is called a comment. Comments are ignored by the computer when executing the program. They are usually used to explain parts of code

#### Naming Variables

Variables should usually be named using alphabetical characters. For example: `sum`, `number`, `grade`, `money`

If you want your variable's name to contain multiple words then you should start each word in the name with an uppercase letter except for the first one. For example you want a variable that holds the number of students in a class than you should name it `numberOfStudents` instead of `numberofstudents` because the first  one is more readable.

If you read your code after 2 months you most likely won't remember what `n` means. But `numberOfStudents` is immediately obvious.

When dealing with numbers that don't represent something it's ok to use single letter names.

#### Basic Operators

You can write arithmetic expressions using numbers, variables, operators and parentheses. 

```swift
// The + operator returns the sum of two numbers
let sum = 1 + 2 // 3

// The - operator returns the difference of two numbers
let diff = 5 - sum // 5 - 3 = 2

// The * operator returns the product of two numbers
let mul = sum * diff // 3 * 2 = 6

// The / operator returns the numbers of times the  divisor(the number on 
// the right side) divides into the dividend(the number on the left side)
// For example, when dividing 6 by 3, the quotient is 2, while 6 is called
// the dividend, and 3 the divisor.

let div = mul / diff // 6 / 2 = 3

// The remainder(modulo) operator returns the remainder of the division 
let mod = 7 % 3 // 1 because 7/3 = 2 and remainder 1 (2 * 3 + 1 = 7)

// You can use parentheses to group operations
(1 + 1) * (5 - 2) 

// Multiplication, division and remainder have higher precedence than 
// addition and subtraction.
// For example: 5 + 2 * 3 = 5 + 6 = 11
```

#### Integer Division

Addition, subtraction and multiplication behave pretty much as you expect. The tricky operations are division and remainder.  
Take for example `5 / 2`. Normally you'd expect the result to be `2.5`. In Swift dividing two integers also produces an integer this is acomplished by discarding the part of the number after the decimal point. So `5 / 2 = 2`.  
The remainder operator or modulo operator (%) is used to get the remainder of an integer division. `5 % 2 = 1`  
For `5 / 2`:  
`quotient = 5 / 2 = 2`  
`remainder = 5 % 2 = 1`  
`quotient * 2 + remainder = 5`  

Generally speaking for two integers `a` and `b` this equations always hold  
`quotient = a / b`  
`remainder = a % b`  
`b * quotient + remainder = a`

**NOTICE:** `remainder = a - b * quotient`  
This implies that `remainder = a - b * (a / b)`  and  
`a % b = a - b * (a / b)`  
You can view `a % b` as a shorthand way of computing `a - b * (a / b)`

**NOTICE:** if `a % b = 0` then `b` divides `a`, that is `a` is a multiple of `b`.  
Example:   
`15 / 5 = 3`  
`15 % 5 = 0` ->  
`15 = 5 * 3`

#### Order of statemets and more Playgrounds

The order of statements in a program matters. Like lists of instructions programs are executed from top to bottom.

```swift
var numberOfApples = 7 // you have 7 apples
var numberOfOranges = 2 // you have 2 orages

// you eat an apple (numberOfApples = 6)
numberOfApples = numberOfApples - 1 

// a wizard doubles your oranges (numberOfOranges = 4)
numberOfOranges = numberOfOranges * 2 

var stashedFruits = numberOfApples + numberOfOranges // 10 (6 + 4)

// you receive 2 apples (numberOfApples = 8). stashedFruits remains unchanged!
numberOfApples += 2 

stashedFruits /= 2 // you lose half your stashed fruits 5 (10 / 2)
```

In the program above the variable `stashedFruits` gets a value only after all the previous statements are run. Also notice that the value assigned to a variable is computed at the time of assignment. Changing `numberOfApples` after declaring `stashedFruits` will not have any effect on the value of `stashedFruits`.

Looking at the code above in a playground will give you an idea of why playgrounds are incredibly helpful for visualizing how code behaves.

As you can see each line of code in a playground has the value of the expression on that line printed in the right area of the screen.

![Playground 1](https://www.weheartswift.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/Screen-Shot-2015-02-09-at-8.15.52-PM.png)

Now, the cool thing is that if we modify any values. All lines are imediatelly updated to reflect our changes.
For example we modify:

```swift
var numberOfApples = 25
var numberOfOranges = 30
```

and everything is recalculated and displayed immediately.

![Playground 2](https://www.weheartswift.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/Screen-Shot-2015-02-09-at-8.16.13-PM.png)

Try playing around!

#### Print Statement

After making some computations you will want to show your results somehow. The simplest way to do it is with `print()` statement.  

```swift
// will print Hello Swift! in the console 
// you can print any text between quotes
print("Hello Swift!") 

print(1 + 2) // will print 3

var ten = 10

print(ten) // will print 10
```

To see the console output in Playground make sure to show the `Debug Area`. 

You can do that by pressing the middle button from the top right corner of the Playground.

![](https://www.weheartswift.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/09/Screen-Shot-2015-09-25-at-18.09.091-e1443194066271.png)

Or from the menu:

![](http://www.weheartswift.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/Screen-Shot-2014-12-01-at-17.38.53.png)

exercises.content:
### 1.1 Sum

You are given two variables `a` and `b`, compute their sum and store it in another variable named `sum` then print the result.

```swift
var a = 1
var b = 2

// your code here
```

[spoiler title="Example 1" collapse_link="true"]  
Input:
```swift
var a = 1 
var b = 2 
```

Expected values:
```swift
sum = 3
```

Output: 
```
3
```
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title="Example 2" collapse_link="true"]  
Input:
```swift
var a = 13 
var b = 22 
```

Expected values:
```swift
sum = 35
```

Output: 
```
35
```
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Solution' collapse_link='true']
```swift
var a = 1
var b = 2

var sum = a + b

print(sum)
```
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Explanation']

To solve this problem we will create a variable named `sum` and initialize it with the sum of `a` and `b` (`a + b`). The next step is to print the value of `sum` using a print statement.

[/spoiler]

exercises.content:
### 1.2 Seconds

Determine the number of seconds in a year and store the number in a variable named `secondsInAYear`.

```swift
// your code here
```

[spoiler title='Hint' collapse_link='true']

The number of seconds in a year is 365 times the number of seconds in a day.  
The number of seconds in a day is 24 times the number of seconds in a hour.  
The number of seconds in a hour is 60 times the number of seconds in a minute, which is 60. 

[/spoiler]


[spoiler title='Solution' collapse_link='true']
```swift
let secondsInAMinute = 60

// The number of seconds in a hour is 60 times the number 
// of seconds in a minute, which is 60.
let secondsInAHour = 60 * secondsInAMinute

// The number of seconds in a day is 24x the number of seconds in a hour. 
let secondsInADay = 24 * secondsInAHour

// The number of seconds in a year is 365x the number of seconds in a day. 
let secondsInAYear = 365 * secondsInADay
```
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Explanation']
To keep the math simple are are going to make only one multiplication on each line. We are going to compute the number of seconds in a hour, day and year starting from the number of seconds in a minute.
[/spoiler]

exercises.content:
### 1.3 Pixels

Your are given the `width` and `height` of a screen in pixels. Calculate the total number of pixels on the screen and store the result in a variable named `numberOfPixels`.

```swift
var width = 1920 
var height = 1080

// your code here
```

[spoiler title="Example 1" collapse_link="true"]  
Input:
```swift
var width = 4
var height = 3 
```

Expected values:  
```swift
numberOfPixels = 12
```

[/spoiler]

[spoiler title="Example 2" collapse_link="true"]  
Input:
```swift
var width = 1920
var height = 1080
```

Expected values:  
```swift
numberOfPixels = 2073600
```

[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Hint' collapse_link='true']  
Consider a 5x3 screen like this:

```
*****
*****
*****
```

The number of pixels on this screen is 5 + 5 + 5 = 5 * 3  
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Solution' collapse_link='true']

```swift
var width = 1920 
var height = 1080

var numberOfPixels = width * height
```

[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Explanation']

The screen can be seen as a rectangle of size width x height. The number of pixels on the screen is equal to the area of the rectangle, which is `width * height`.

[/spoiler]

exercises.content:
### 1.4 Sum and Difference

You are given the `sum` and the `difference` of two numbers. Find out the values of the original numbers and store them in variables `a` and `b`.

```swift
let sum = 16 // a + b 
let diff = 4 // a - b

// your code here
```

[spoiler title="Example 1" collapse_link="true"]  
Input:
```swift
var sum = 16 
var dif = 4
```

Expected values:
```swift
a = 10
b = 6
```

[/spoiler]

[spoiler title="Example 2" collapse_link="true"]  
Input:
```swift
var sum = 2 
var dif = 0
```

Expected values:
```swift
a = 1
b = 1
```

[/spoiler]

[spoiler title="Example 3" collapse_link="true"]  
Input:
```swift
var sum = 4 
var dif = 2
```

Expected values:
```swift
a = 3
b = 1
```

[/spoiler]


[spoiler title='Hint 1' collapse_link='true']  
`sum + diff = a + a + b - b`  
`sum + diff = 2 * a`  
[/spoiler]  

[spoiler title='Hint 2' collapse_link='true']  
`sum = a + b`  
`b = sum - a`  
[/spoiler]  

[spoiler title='Solution' collapse_link='true']
```swift
let sum = 16 // a + b
let diff = 4 // a - b

// sum + diff = a + b + a - b = a + a = 2*a 
// -> sum + diff = 2*a 
// -> a = (sum + diff) / 2

var a = (sum + diff) / 2 // 10
var b = sum - a // 6
```
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Explanation']

We notice that if we add the sum and the difference of two numbers we get the double of one of them:

```
sum + diff = 
(a + b) + (a - b) = 
a + a = 2*a 
```

To get one of the numbers (`a`) we will half the sum of `sum` and `diff`. 
To get the other one (`b`) we can subtract the first one (`a`) from their `sum`.

[/spoiler]

exercises.content:
### 1.5 L Area

You are given four variables `width`, `height`, `x`, `y` that describe the dimensions of a L-shape as shown in the image below. Determine the `perimeter` and `area` of the described L-shape. Store the value of the perimeter in a variable named `perimeter`, and the area in a variable named `area`.

![](http://www.weheartswift.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/10/l-shape-e1414514986551.png)

```swift
var width = 8
var height = 12
var x = 2
var y = 3

// your code here
```

[spoiler title="Example 1" collapse_link="true"]  
Input:
```swift
var width = 8
var height = 12
var x = 4
var y = 3
```
Expected values:
```swift
perimeter = 40
area = 60
```
![Example1](https://www.weheartswift.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/rectangle1-e1423241137674.png)
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title="Example 2" collapse_link="true"]  
Input:
```swift
var width = 8 
var height = 4
var x = 2
var y = 2
```

Expected values:
```swift
perimeter = 24
area = 20
```

![Example2](https://www.weheartswift.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/rectangle2-e1423241026456.png)

[/spoiler]

[spoiler title="Hint" collapse_link='true']

The `perimeter` of the L-shape is the same as of a rectangle of size `width X height`.   

To compute the `area` you can imagine the L-shape as rectangle of size `width X height` with a rectangle of size `(width-x) X (height-y)` cut out. 

[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Solution' collapse_link='true']
```swift
var width = 8
var height = 12
var x = 4
var y = 3

var perimeter = 2 * (width + height)

var bigArea = width * height
var smallArea = (width - x) * (height - y)
var area = bigArea - smallArea
```
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Explanation']

The `perimeter` of the L-shape is the same as of a rectangle of size `width X height`.  Which is equal to 2 * (width + height).

To compute the `area` you can imagine the L-shape as rectangle of size `width X height` with a rectangle of size `(width-x) X (height-y)` cut out. We compute the area of the big rectangle as `width * height` and the area of the small rectangle as `(width - x) * (height - y)`. Their difference gives us the total area.

[/spoiler]

```swift
var bigArea = width * height
var smallArea = (width - x) * (height - y)
var area = bigArea - smallArea
```
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Explanation']

The `perimeter` of the L-shape is the same as of a rectangle of size `width X height`.  Which is equal to 2 * (width + height).

To compute the `area` you can imagine the L-shape as rectangle of size `width X height` with a rectangle of size `(width-x) X (height-y)` cut out. We compute the area of the big rectangle as `width * height` and the area of the small rectangle as `(width - x) * (height - y)`. Their difference gives us the total area.

[/spoiler]

exercises.content:
### 1.6 Swap

Given two variable `a` and `b`, swap their values. That is the new value of `a` will become the old value of `b` and vice versa.

```swift
var a = 1
var b = 2

// your code here
```

[spoiler title="Example 1" collapse_link="true"]  
Input:
```swift
var a = 1
var b = 2
```

Expected values:
```swift
a = 2
b = 1
```

[/spoiler]

[spoiler title="Example 2" collapse_link="true"]  
Input:
```swift
var a = 13
var b = 7582
```

Expected values:
```swift
a = 7582
b = 13
```

[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Hint 1' collapse_link='true']

Just assigning `a` to the value of `b` and `b` to the value of `a` will not work.  

```swift
var a = 1
var b = 2

a = b // a will have the value 2. The original value of a is lost
b = a // b will remain the same
```
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Hint 2' collapse_link='true']
Use a third variable to save the original value of `a`.
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Solution' collapse_link='true']
```swift
var a = 1
var b = 2

var temp = a
a = b
b = temp
```
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Explanation']

First we'll keep a backup of the value of `a` in a new variable `temp`. We'll assign `a` to `b` which will overwrite the current value of `a` (`a` will now be equal to `b`). Next we assign to `b` the backed up value of `a` which is stored in `temp`. A useful analogy: Imagine you have 2 glasses and you want to interchange their contents. To accomplish this, you'll have to use a 3rd glass to temporarly hold the contents of one of them.

[/spoiler]

exercises.content:
### 1.7 Last digit

You are given a number `a`. Print the last digit of `a`.

```swift
var a = 123

// your code here
```

[spoiler title="Example 2" collapse_link="true"]  
Input:
```swift
var a = 123
```

Output:
```
3
```

[/spoiler]

[spoiler title="Example 2" collapse_link="true"]  
Input:
```swift
var a = 337
```

Output:
```
7
```

[/spoiler]

[spoiler title="Example 3" collapse_link="true"]  
Input:
```swift
var a = 100
```

Output:
```
0
```

[/spoiler]


[spoiler title='Hint' collapse_link='true']
Use the remainder `%` operator.  
Remember that `a = k * (a / k) + a % k`  
Can you think of a value for k that gives the last digit?
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Solution' collapse_link='true']
```swift
var a = 123

print(a % 10)
```
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Explanation']
You can get the last digit of a number by computing the reminder of division by `10`. 
[/spoiler]

exercises.content:
### 1.8 Dog Years

You are given Rocky's age in dog years. Print Rocky's age in human years. You know that 1 human year is 7 dog years.

```swift
var rockysAge = 50

// your code here
```

[spoiler title="Example 1" collapse_link="true"]  
Input:
```swift
var rockysAge = 50
```

Output:
```
7
```
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title="Example 2" collapse_link="true"]  
Input:
```swift
var rockysAge = 14
```

Output:
```
2
```
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title="Example 3" collapse_link="true"]  
Input:
```swift
var rockysAge = 15
```

Output:
```
2
```

[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Hint' collapse_link='true']  
Use division.
[/spoiler]  

[spoiler title='Solution' collapse_link='true']
```swift
var rockysAge = 50

var rockysAgeInHumanYears = rockysAge / 7

print(rockysAgeInHumanYears) // 7
```
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Explanation']

The problem is solved using a division by `7`. If `7` dog years = `1` human year then `X` dog years is equal to `X / 7` human years.

[/spoiler]

exercises.content:
### 1.9 Brothers

Everyone hates solving word problems by hand so let's make a program to solve them for us.  
`x` years from now Alice will be `y` times older than her brother Bob. Bob is `12` years old. How many years does Alice have?  

[spoiler title="Code" collapse_link="true" compile="false"]
```swift
var x = 3
var y = 2
var bob = 12 

var alice = ?
// your code here
```
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title="Example 1" collapse_link="true"]  

Input:
```swift
var x = 3
var y = 2
var bob = 12
```

Expected values:
```swift
alice = 27
```

[/spoiler]

[spoiler title="Example 2" collapse_link="true"]  

Input:
```swift
var x = 1
var y = 3
var bob = 12
```

Expected values:
```swift
alice = 38
```

[/spoiler]


[spoiler title='Hint' collapse_link='true']  
`alice + x = y * (bob + x)`  
Solve for `alice` 
[/spoiler]  

[spoiler title='Solution' collapse_link='true']
```swift
var x = 3
var y = 2
var bob = 12

// alice + x = (bob + x) * y
// alice = (bob + x) * y - x
var alice = (bob + x) * y - x
```
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Explanation']

We know that `x` years from now Alice will be `y` times older then her brother. We also know that her brother is currently 12 years old. Mathematically we can say that `alice + x = y * (bob + x)`. Solving this equation for `alice` gives us `alice = y * (bob + x) - x`. This can be straightforwardly written in code.

[/spoiler]

exercises.content:
### 1.10 Apples and Oranges

You have `x` apples. Bob trades `3` oranges for `5` apples. He does not accept trades with cut fruit.  
How many oranges can you get from Bob and how many apples will you have left?

The number of apples you will have left should be stored in a variable named `apples`. The number of oranges you will have after the trade should be stored in a variable named `oranges`.

```swift
var x = 17

// your code here
```

[spoiler title="Example 1" collapse_link="true"]  

Input:
```swift
var x = 17
```

Expected values:
```swift
apples = 2
oranges = 9
```

[/spoiler]

[spoiler title="Example 2" collapse_link="true"]  

Input:
```swift
var x = 25
```

Expected values:
```swift
apples = 0
oranges = 15
```

[/spoiler]

[spoiler title="Example 3" collapse_link="true"]  

Input:
```swift
var x = 4
```

Expected values:
```swift
apples = 4
oranges = 0
```

[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Hint' collapse_link='true']  
Use the division(`/`) and the remainder(`%`) operator  
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Solution' collapse_link='true']
```swift
var x = 17

var apples = x % 5
var oranges = x / 5 * 3
```
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Explanation']

Bob trades 3 oranges for 5 apples. If the number of apples we have would be divideable by 5 then we could trade all our apples for oranges. The number of oranges we would have would be `(x / 5) * 3` and the number of apples would be `0`. If the number of apples we have is not divisible by 5 then we can still get the number of oranges using `(x / 5) * 3` because integer divison ignores any remainder. The number of apples we would be left with would be exactly the reminder of our division that is `x % 5`.

[/spoiler]

var oranges = x / 5 * 3
codes.text:
```swift
var x = 17

var apples = x % 5
var oranges = x / 5 * 3
```

spoilers.content: Bob trades 3 oranges for 5 apples. If the number of apples we have would be divideable by 5 then we could trade all our apples for oranges. The number of oranges we would have would be `(x / 5) * 3` and the number of apples would be `0`. If the number of apples we have is not divisible by 5 then we can still get the number of oranges using `(x / 5) * 3` because integer divison ignores any remainder. The number of apples we would be left with would be exactly the reminder of our division that is `x % 5`.
spoilers.text:
[spoiler title='Explanation']

Bob trades 3 oranges for 5 apples. If the number of apples we have would be divideable by 5 then we could trade all our apples for oranges. The number of oranges we would have would be `(x / 5) * 3` and the number of apples would be `0`. If the number of apples we have is not divisible by 5 then we can still get the number of oranges using `(x / 5) * 3` because integer divison ignores any remainder. The number of apples we would be left with would be exactly the reminder of our division that is `x % 5`.

[/spoiler]

exercises.content:
### 1.11 Boys and Girls

A class consists of `numberOfBoys` boys and `numberOfGirls` girls.   
Print the percentage of boys in the class followed by the percentage of girls in the class. The percentage should be printed rounded down to the nearest integer.   For example `33.333333333333` will be printed as `33`.

```swift
var numberOfBoys = 20
var numberOfGirls = 60

// your code here
```

[spoiler title="Example 1" collapse_link="true"]  
Input:
```swift
var numberOfBoys = 20  
var numberOfGirls = 60  
```

Output:
```
25 // percentage of boys
75 // percentage of girls
```

[/spoiler]

[spoiler title="Example 2" collapse_link="true"]  
Input:
```swift
var numberOfBoys = 20  
var numberOfGirls = 20  
```

Output:
```
50 // percentage of boys
50 // percentage of girls
```

[/spoiler]

[spoiler title="Example 3" collapse_link="true"]  
Input:
```swift
var numberOfBoys = 10  
var numberOfGirls = 20  
```

Output:
```
33 // percentage of boys
66 // percentage of girls
```

[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Hint' collapse_link='true']  
First you'll have to compute the total number of students in the class 
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Hint 1' collapse_link='true']  
`numberOfStudents` ... `100%`  
`numberOfBoys` ... `X%`  
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Hint 2' collapse_link='true']  
`numberOfStudents / 100` = `numberOfBoys / X`
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Solution' collapse_link='true']
```swift
var numberOfBoys = 20
var numberOfGirls = 60

var numberOfStudents = numberOfBoys + numberOfGirls
var boyPercentage = numberOfBoys * 100 / numberOfStudents
print(boyPercentage)
var girlPercentage = numberOfGirls * 100 / numberOfStudents 
print(girlPercentage)
```
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Explanation']

The problem can be solved using [Cross Multiplication](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cross-multiplication). `numberOfStudents / 100 = numberOfBoys / boyPercentage`. This gives us `boyPercentage = numberOfBoys * 100 / numberOfStudents`. Simillarly for the girl percentage we have `numberOfStudents / 100 = numberOfGirls / girlPercentage` giving us `girlPercentage = numberOfGirls * 100 / numberOfStudents`.

[/spoiler]

exercises.content:
### 2.1 Max

You are given two numbers `a` and `b` print the largest one.

```swift
var a = 11
var b = 22

// your code here
```

[spoiler title='Example 1' collapse_link='true']  
Input: 
```swift
var a = 11
var b = 22
```

Output: 
```
22
```
[/spoiler]


[spoiler title='Example 2' collapse_link='true']  
Input: 
```swift
var a = 23 
var b = 12 
```

Output: 
```
23
```
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Example 3' collapse_link='true']  
Input: 
```swift
var a = 2 
var b = 4   
```

Output: 
```
4
```
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Solution' collapse_link='true']
```swift
var a = 11
var b = 23

if a > b {
    print(a)
} else {
    print(b)
}
```
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Explanation']

The maximum of two numbers is the largest of the two numbers. i.e. if a > b then the maximum is a otherwise it's be. Note that this problem can also be solved using `>=` or by using the condition `b < a` and interchanging the order of the print statements.

[/spoiler]

exercises.content:
### 2.2 Even or Odd

You are given a `number`. Print `even` if the number is even or `odd` otherwise.

```swift
let number = 2

// your code here
```

[spoiler title='Example 1' collapse_link='true']  
Input: 
```swift
var number = 1
```

Output: 
```
odd
```
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Example 2' collapse_link='true']  
Input: 
```swift
var number = 12
```

Output: 
```
even
```
[/spoiler]


[spoiler title='Hint' collapse_link='true']  
Use the remainder (`%`) operator to determine if the number is `even` or `odd`  
[/spoiler]  

[spoiler title='Solution' collapse_link='true']  
```swift
let number = 2

if number % 2 == 0 {
	print("even")
} else {
	print("odd")
}
```
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Explanation']

A number is even if it devides evenly into 2. That is the remainder of the division with 2 is 0. Otherwise the number is odd. We'll have to check if the remainder is equal to 0 and print "even" or "odd" accordingly. 

[/spoiler]

exercises.content:
### 2.3 Divisibility

You are given two numbers `a` and `b`. Print `"divisible"` if `a` is divisible by `b` and `"not divisible"` otherwise.

```swift
var a = 12
var b = 3

// your code here
```

[spoiler title='Example 1' collapse_link='true']  
Input: 
```swift
var a = 22
var b = 11  
```

Output: 
```
divisible
```
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Example 2' collapse_link='true']  
Input: 
```swift
var a = 12 
var b = 3   
```

Output: 
```
divisible
```
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Example 3' collapse_link='true']  
Input: 
```swift
var a = 12 
var b = 5   
```

Output: 
```
not divisible
```
[/spoiler]


[spoiler title='Hint 1' collapse_link='true']  
Use the remainder (`%`) operator to check if `b` divides `a`.
[/spoiler]  

[spoiler title='Hint 2' collapse_link='true']  
To check if `b` divides `a` you need to check if the remainder of the division of `a` to `b` is 0.
[/spoiler]  


[spoiler title='Solution' collapse_link='true']
```swift
var a = 12
var b = 3

if a % b == 0 {
    print("divisible")
} else {
    print("not divisible")
}
```
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Explanation']

A number `a` is divisible by a number `b` if the remainder of the division is `0`. We'll have to check if that is the case and print a message accordingly.

[/spoiler]

exercises.content:
### 2.4 Two of the same

You are given three variables `a`, `b` and `c`. Check if at least two variables have the same value. If that is true print `At least two variables have the same value` otherwise print `All the values are different`.

```swift
var a = 2
var b = 3
var c = 2

// your code here
```

[spoiler title='Example 1' collapse_link='true']
Input: 
```swift
var a = 1 
var b = 2  
var c = 3
```

Output: 
```
All the values are different
```
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Example 2' collapse_link='true']
Input: 
```swift
var a = 1 
var b = 2  
var c = 1
```

Output: 
```
At least two variables have the same value
```
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Example 3' collapse_link='true']
Input: 
```swift
var a = 3 
var b = 3  
var c = 3
```

Output: 
```
At least two variables have the same value
```
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Hint' collapse_link='true']  
Use the OR (`||`) operator to chain multiple equality checks 
[/spoiler]  

[spoiler title='Solution' collapse_link='true']
```swift
var a = 2
var b = 2
var c = 2

if (a == b) || (a == c) || (b == c) {
    print("At least two variables have the same value")
} else {
    print("All the values are different")
}
```
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Explanation' collapse_link='true']
To check if at least two variables have the same value we only have to check 3 of the posible 6 pairs(ab, ac, ba, bc, ca, cb) because equality is symmetric (is a = b then b = a). 
[/spoiler]

twists.content:
#### Twist

Check if all three variables are the same.

[spoiler title='Hint' collapse_link='true']  
Use the AND (`&&`) operator to chain multiple equality checks  
[/spoiler]  

[spoiler title='Solution' collapse_link='true']
```swift
var a = 2
var b = 2
var c = 2

if (a == b) && (b == c) {
    print("All three variables have the same value")
}
```
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Explanation' collapse_link='true']
Because equality is transitive (if a = b and b = c then a = c) we only need to check two pairs of variables for equality to determine if all of them have the same value. 
[/spoiler]

exercises.content:
### 2.5 Breakfast

You are working on a smart-fridge. The smart-fridge knows how old the eggs and bacon in it are. You know that eggs spoil after 3 weeks (`21 days`) and bacon after one week (`7 days`).  
Given `baconAge` and `eggsAge`(in days) determine if you can cook bacon and eggs or what ingredients you need to throw out.  
If you can cook bacon and eggs print `you can cook bacon and eggs`.  
If you need to throw out any ingredients for each one print a line with the text `throw out ingredient` (`throw out bacon` or `throw out eggs`) in any order.

```swift
var baconAge = 6 // the bacon is 6 days old
var eggsAge = 12 // eggs are 12 days old

// your code here
```

[spoiler title='Example 1' collapse_link='true']
Input:  
```swift
var baconAge = 3
var eggsAge = 2
```

Output:  
```
you can cook bacon and eggs  
```
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Example 2' collapse_link='true'] 
Input:
```swift
var baconAge = 9
var eggsAge = 20
```

Output:  
```
throw out bacon  
```
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Example 3' collapse_link='true']
Input:  
```swift
var baconAge = 9
var eggsAge = 23
```
Output:  
```
throw out bacon  
throw out eggs
```
[/spoiler] 


[spoiler title='Hint 1' collapse_link='true']  
Check for the case where `you can cook bacon and eggs` first.
[/spoiler] 

[spoiler title='Hint 2' collapse_link='true']  
In the else branch check the ingredients that need to be thrown out.
[/spoiler] 

[spoiler title='Solution' collapse_link='true']
```swift
var baconAge = 6
var eggsAge = 12

if baconAge <= 7 && eggsAge <= 21 {
	// bacon and eggs are ok, we can cook
	print("you can cook bacon and eggs")
} else {
	// either eggs or bacon or both are spoiled
	if baconAge > 7 {
		print("throw out bacon")
	}
	if eggsAge > 21 {
		print("throw out eggs")
	}
}
```
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Explanation']

The only case where we can cook bacon and eggs is when the bacon's age is less than or equal to 7 and the egg's age is less than or equal to 21. In code this is equivalent to the conditions `baconAge <= 7` and `eggsAge <= 21`. To check that both these conditions are true we use the `&&` operator. In case one of these conditions is not met we check which ingredients have gone bad (`baconAge > 7` or `eggsAge > 21`) and print a message accordingly.

[/spoiler]

exercises.content:
### 2.6 Leap Year

You are given a `year`, determine if it's a `leap year`. A `leap year` is a year containing an extra day. It has `366 days` instead of the normal `365 days`. The extra day is added in February, which has `29 days` instead of the normal `28 days`. Leap years occur every `4 years`. `2012` was a `leap year` and `2016` will also be a `leap year`.  
The above rule is valid except that every `100 years` special rules apply. Years that are divisible by `100` are not `leap years` if they are not also divisible by `400`. For example `1900` was not a `leap year`, but `2000` was.
Print  `Leap year!` or `Not a leap year!` depending on the case.

```swift
let year = 2014

// your code here
```


[spoiler title='Example 1' collapse_link='true']
Input:  
```swift
var year = 2000 
```
Output: 
```
Leap year!
```
[/spoiler]  

[spoiler title='Example 2' collapse_link='true']
Input:  
```swift
var year = 2005 
```
Output: 
```
Not a leap year!
```
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Example 3' collapse_link='true']
Input:  
```swift
var year = 1900
```
Output: 
```
Not a leap year!
```
[/spoiler]  

[spoiler title='Example 4' collapse_link='true']  
Input:  
```swift
var year = 1992
```
Output: 
```
Leap year!
```
[/spoiler]  

[spoiler title='Hint' collapse_link='true']  
Use the remainder (`%`) operator to check for divisibility by `4`. Don't forget to check the special case when `year` is divisible by `100`.
[/spoiler] 

[spoiler title='Solution' collapse_link='true']
```swift
let year = 2014
if year % 4 == 0 {
    if year % 100 == 0 && year % 400 != 0 {
        print("Not a leap year!")
    } else {
        print("Leap year!")
    }
} else {
	print(year, terminator: "")
    print("Not a leap year!")
}
```
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Explanation']

First we'll check for divisibility by 4. Next we'll check if the year is divisible by 100 and not divisible by 400, if that's the case then the year is not a leap year despide being divisible by 4, otherwise it is a leap year. If the year is not divisible by 4 then its certainly not a leap year.

[/spoiler]

```
4
```

[spoiler title='Hint' collapse_link='true']

[/spoiler] 

[spoiler title='Solution' collapse_link='true']
```swift
var a = 5
var b = 6
var c = 3
var d = 4

var min = a

if b < min {
    min = b
}

if c < min {
    min = c
}

if d < min {
    min = d
}

print(min)
```
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Explanation']

We start by assuming that the minimum is equal to `a`. Next we check if `b`, `c` or `d` are less than our current minimum, updating our minimum if that is the case. **Note:** We could have used 4 conditions of the form `if a <= b && a <= c && a <= d` but that would have resulted in a more complicated solution.

[/spoiler]

exercises.content:
### 2.9 Testing

Test if `number` is divisible by `3`, `5` and `7`. For example `105` is divisible by `3`, `5` and `7`, but `120` is divisible only by `3` and `5` but not by `7`. If `number` is divisible by `3`, `5` and `7` print `number is divisible by 3, 5 and 7` otherwise print `number is not divisible by 3, 5 and 7`.

```swift
let number = 210

// your code here
```

[spoiler title='Example 1' collapse_link='true']   
Input: 
```swift
var number = 60
```
Output: 
```
number is not divisible by 3, 5 and 7  
```
[/spoiler]  

[spoiler title='Example 2' collapse_link='true']  
Input: 
```swift
var number = 105
```

Output: 
```
number is divisible by 3, 5 and 7  
```
[/spoiler]  

[spoiler title='Hint' collapse_link='true']  
Use the remainder (`%`) operator to check for divisibility.
[/spoiler] 

[spoiler title='Solution' collapse_link='true']
```swift
let number = 210

if number % 3 == 0 && number % 5 == 0 && number % 7 == 0 {
	print("number is divisible by 3, 5 and 7")
} else {
	print("number is not divisible by 3, 5 and 7")
}
```
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Explanation']

We'll have to check if the number is simultaneously divisible by 3, 5 and 7. We combine these divisibility checks via the `&&` operator.

[/spoiler]

exercises.content:
### 2.10 Point

Find out if the point (`x`, `y`) is inside of the rectangle with the lower-left corner in (`lowX`, `lowY`) and the upper-right in (`highX`, `highY`). Print `inside` or `not inside` depending on the case.

```swift
var x = 1
var y = 2
var lowX = 1
var lowY = 1
var highX = 3
var highY = 3

// your code here
```

[spoiler title='Example 1' collapse_link='true']  

Input: 
```swift
var x = 1
var y = 2
var lowX = 1
var lowY = 1
var highX = 3
var highY = 3
```

Output: 
```
"inside"
```

![Point 1](https://www.weheartswift.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/point1.png)

[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Example 2' collapse_link='true']  

Input: 
```swift
var x = 2
var y = 2
var lowX = 1
var lowY = 1
var highX = 3
var highY = 3
```

Output: 
```
"inside"
```

![Point 2](https://www.weheartswift.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/point2.png)

[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Example 3' collapse_link='true']  

Input: 
```swift
var x = 4
var y = 4
var lowX = 0
var lowY = 0
var highX = 3
var highY = 5
```

Output: 
```
"not inside"
```

![Point 3](https://www.weheartswift.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/point3.png)

[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Hint' collapse_link='true']  
Chain multiple comparisons together using the AND (`&&`) operator.
[/spoiler] 

[spoiler title='Solution' collapse_link='true']
```swift
var x = 1
var y = 2
var lowX = 1
var lowY = 1
var highX = 3
var highY = 3

if x >= lowX && y >= lowY && x <= highX && y <= highY {
    print("inside")
} else {
    print("not inside")
}
```
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Explanation']

The point is inside the rectangle if it's x coordinate is greater or equal to the rectangle's lowest x coordinate (lowX) and less than or equal to the rectangles highest x coordinate (highX). We'll also have to do a simillar check for the y coordinate.

[/spoiler]

```swift
var x = 1
var y = 2
var lowX = 1
var lowY = 1
var highX = 3
var highY = 3
```

```swift
if x >= lowX && y >= lowY && x <= highX && y <= highY {
    print("inside")
} else {
    print("not inside")
}
```
[/spoiler]

exercises.content:
### 2.11 Hitpoints

You are working on a videogame where the character has a certain number of hitpoints(HP) ranging from `0` to `100`.  
`100` represents full health  
`0` represents dead.  
You want to add regenerating health to the game using the following rules:

-  HP always regenerates up to numbers of the form `X0` (`75` -> `80` , `32` -> `40` ...)
-  When HP is below `20` it regenerates up to `20` (`13` -> `20`, `5` -> `20`, ...)
-  If the character has `0` HP then he doesn't regenerate life (he's dead)

Given the current hp of the character stored in a variable `hp` print the `hp` the player will have after regenerating life.

```swift
var hp = 75

// your code here
```


[spoiler title='Example 1' collapse_link='true']    
Input: 
```swift 
var hp = 60
```

Output: 
```
60
```
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Example 2' collapse_link='true']   
Input: 
```swift 
var hp = 26
```

Output: 
```
30  
```
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Example 3' collapse_link='true']   
Input: 
```swift 
var hp = 12
```
Output: 
```
20
```
[/spoiler]  

[spoiler title='Example 4' collapse_link='true']   
Input: 
```swift 
var hp = 4 
```

Output: 
```
20
```
[/spoiler]  

[spoiler title='Example 5' collapse_link='true']   
Input: 
```swift 
var hp = 95
```

Output: 
```
100
```
[/spoiler]  

[spoiler title='Hint' collapse_link='true']  
Check for the case when `hp` is between 1 and 19 first
[/spoiler] 

[spoiler title='Hint' collapse_link='true']  
Discard the last digit of `hp` via division
[/spoiler] 

[spoiler title='Solution' collapse_link='true']
```swift
var hp = 75

if hp > 0 && hp < 20 {
    hp = 20
} else if hp % 10 != 0 {
    hp = hp / 10
    hp = hp + 1
    hp = hp * 10
}

print(hp)
```
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Explanation']

Lets start with the simple case, if `hp` is greater than `0` and less than `20` we just set it to `20`. Otherwise we want to round `hp` to the next multiple of `10` if `hp` is not already a multiple of `10` (`hp` is divisible by `10`). To round an integer to the next multiple of `10` we divide by `10` and add `1` then multiply by `10`.

[/spoiler]

content:
## 3. Types

#### Introduction

All the values we've worked with so far have been integer numbers.  
All variables and constants in Swift have a type. Think of the type as describing what kind of values a variable can have. The type for integer numbers is `Int`.

You can see the type of a variable in Xcode by option clicking on it's name (hold down option() and click on its name). A popup will appear were you can see the type of the variable.

![lucky](https://www.weheartswift.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/lucky.png)

Here you can see that our lucky number 7 is of type `Int`.

We often need variables of types that aren't `Int`. You already encountered a different type. The expresssions inside an if statement. These values have type `Bool` also known as `Boolean` named after mathematician [George Boole](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_Boole) who layed out the mathematical foundations of Logic.

Comparision operators (`<,<=,>,>=,==,!=`) produce values of type `Bool`. Boolean expressions can have only one of 2 types `true` or `false`

For example

```swift
var luckyNumber = 7

var condition = 777 > luckyNumber
```  
`condition` will be of type `Bool` and have a value of `true` as seen below:

![luckier](https://www.weheartswift.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/luckier.png)

#### The Double type

What if we want to use numbers of the form (`1.5, 1.7, 1.6,...`)?
We can of course do that in Swift! If you declare a variable lets say `heightInMeters` with a value of `1.85` and check its type you'll see that its type is `Double`

```swift
var heightInMeters = 1.85
```

![Double](https://www.weheartswift.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/height.png)

Variables of type `Double` hold fractional numbers and can be used for calculating fractional quantities. Any number of the form `X.Y` is a `Double`
Examples: (35.67, 2.0, 0.5154, ...)

Doubles can be added, subtracted, multiplied and divided using the familiar operators (`+, -, *, /`).

There is no equivalent to the remainder(`%`) operator for doubles.

```swift
var a = 3.5
var b = 1.25

print(a + b) // 4.75
print(a - b) // 2.25
print(a * b) // 4.375
print(a / b) // 2.8

``` 

[spoiler title='Why are fractional numbers called Double?(Optional)' collapse_link='true']   
Numbers of type double have a limited precision. consider the following code

```swift
print(1.0 / 3.0) // 0.333333333333333
```

Mathematically speaking the number ( `1.0 / 3.0`) should go on forever having an infinite number of 3s after the  decimal `.`. Computers can't hold an infinite amount of information so they truncate the number at some point.  

Representing decimal numbers in a computer is done via so called [Floating Point Numbers](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Floating_point). Represented by the type `Float` in Swift. The `Double` type is a kind of floating point number but compared to the `Float` type it can hold twice as many digits hence the name `Double` .
[/spoiler]  


#### Declaring variables of a certain type

To explicitly declare a variable of a certain type you use the syntax:

**var** `variable` : `Type` = `...`

For example:

```swift
var integer:Int = 64
var boolean:Bool = false
var double:Double = 7.2
```

If you don't provide a type for a variable a type is automatically inferred for you using the value you provide

Examples:

```swift
// We don't declare a type for a it is implicitly Int 
// because the value 7 is an Int
var a = 7 

print(a / 2) // 3
```

```swift
// We don't declare a type for a it is implicitly Double 
// because the value 7.0 is a Double
var a = 7.0 
print(a / 2) // 3.5
```

If you explicilty declare a variable as having type `Double` then you can initialize it with an integer but the variable will hold a `Double`

```swift
var a:Double = 7 // We explicitly declare a type for a

print(a / 2) // 3.5
```

#### Type Casting

Initializing a variable of type `Double` with an integer only works if you use a constant value. If you try initializing a variable of type `Double` with a variable of type `Int` then you'll get an error.

```swift
var a = 64
var b:Double = a // Error
```

To solve this problem we need to convert the value from `Int` to `Double`. Converting a value of some type to a different type is known as `type casting` or just `casting`.

To cast a variable to a certain type we use `TypeName(variableName)` or the `as` operator, `variableName as TypeName`.
For example:

```swift
var a = 64
var b:Double = Double(a) // b = 64.0
var c:Double = a as Double // c = 64.0
```

Casting a `Double` to an `Int` discards all the digits after the decimal point. Note that this digits can't be recovered by casting the variable back to `Double`.

Example:

```swift
var number = 5.25
var integerNumber = Int(number) // 5
var doubleNumber = Double(integerNumber) // 5.0
```

```swift
var b:Double = a // Error
```

To solve this problem we need to convert the value from `Int` to `Double`. Converting a value of some type to a different type is known as `type casting` or just `casting`.

To cast a variable to a certain type we use `TypeName(variableName)` or the `as` operator, `variableName as TypeName`.
For example:

```swift
var a = 64
var b:Double = Double(a) // b = 64.0
var c:Double = a as Double // c = 64.0
```

Casting a `Double` to an `Int` discards all the digits after the decimal point. Note that this digits can't be recovered by casting the variable back to `Double`.

Example:

```swift
var number = 5.25
var integerNumber = Int(number) // 5
var doubleNumber = Double(integerNumber) // 5.0
```

spoilers.content:
Numbers of type double have a limited precision. consider the following code

```swift
print(1.0 / 3.0) // 0.333333333333333
```

Mathematically speaking the number ( `1.0 / 3.0`) should go on forever having an infinite number of 3s after the  decimal `.`. Computers can't hold an infinite amount of information so they truncate the number at some point.  

Representing decimal numbers in a computer is done via so called [Floating Point Numbers](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Floating_point). Represented by the type `Float` in Swift. The `Double` type is a kind of floating point number but compared to the `Float` type it can hold twice as many digits hence the name `Double` .

Representing decimal numbers in a computer is done via so called [Floating Point Numbers](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Floating_point). Represented by the type `Float` in Swift. The `Double` type is a kind of floating point number but compared to the `Float` type it can hold twice as many digits hence the name `Double` .

exercises.content:
### 3.1 Average

You are given 2 Doubles `a` and `b`. Print their average.

```swift
var a = 2.0
var b = 5.0

// your code here
```

[spoiler title="Example 1" collapse_link="true"]  
Input:
```swift
var a = 2.0
var b = 5.0
```

Output:
```
3.5
```

[/spoiler]

[spoiler title="Example 2" collapse_link="true"]  
Input:
```swift
var a = 20.0
var b = 40.0
```

Output:
```
30.0
```

[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Hint' collapse_link='true']  
Adding 2 numbers together and dividing by 2 gives you their average.  
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Solution' collapse_link='true']  
```swift
var a = 2.0
var b = 5.0

print((a + b) / 2)
```
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Explanation']

We'll just have to add our numbers and divide by 2. Keep in mind that division has higher predence then addition so `(a + b) / 2` is correct while `a + b / 2` would not be correct.

[/spoiler]

exercises.content:
### 3.2 Weighted Average

You are given 3 grades stored in 3 variables of type `Double` `finalsGrade`, `midtermGrade`, `projectGrade`. These grades are used to compute the grade for a class. `finalsGrade` represents 50% of the grade. `midtermGrade` represents 20% of the grade. `projectGrade` represents 30% of the final grade.   
Print the grade for the class.

```swift
var finalsGrade = 2.0
var midtermGrade = 4.0
var projectGrade = 3.0

// your code here
```

[spoiler title="Example 1" collapse_link="true"]  
Input:
```swift
var finalsGrade = 2.0
var midtermGrade = 5.0
var projectGrade = 3.0
```

Output:
```
2.7
```

[/spoiler]

[spoiler title="Example 2" collapse_link="true"]  
Input:
```swift
var finalsGrade = 5.0
var midtermGrade = 5.0
var projectGrade = 5.0
```

Output:
```
5.0
```

[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Hint' collapse_link='true']  

`x%` of a `value` = `value * x / 100`

[/spoiler]  

[spoiler title='Solution' collapse_link='true']  
```swift
var finalsGrade = 2.0
var midtermGrade = 4.0
var projectGrade = 3.0

print(0.5 * finalsGrade + 0.2 * midtermGrade  + 0.3 * projectGrade)
```
[/spoiler]  

[spoiler title='Explanation']

To get `X%` of a value we have to multiply the value by `X / 100`. For 50, 20 and 30 percent we have to multiply with 0.5, 0.2 and 0.3 respectively, these are our weights in the average. The weighted average we need will be the grades multiplied by the correspoding weight.

[/spoiler]

exercises.content:
### 3.3 Tipping

You have the cost of a meal at a restaurant stored in a variable `mealCost` of type `Double`.  
You would like to leave a tip of a certain percentage. The percentage is stored in a variable `tip` of type `Int`.  
Print the total cost of the meal.

```swift
var mealCost:Double = 3.5
var tip:Int = 25 // 25% tip

// your code here
```

[spoiler title="Example 1" collapse_link="true"]  
Input:
```swift
var mealCost:Double = 3.5
var tip:Int = 25
```

Output:
```
4.2
```

[/spoiler]

[spoiler title="Example 2" collapse_link="true"]  
Input:
```swift
var mealCost:Double = 10.0
var tip:Int = 10
```

Output:
```
11.0
```
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Hint 1' collapse_link='true']  
Don't forget to convert `tip` to `Double`  
[/spoiler]  

[spoiler title='Hint 2' collapse_link='true']  
`x%` of a `value` is equal to `value * x / 100`
[/spoiler]  


[spoiler title='Solution' collapse_link='true']
```swift
var mealCost:Double = 3.5
var tip:Int = 20

var tipCost = mealCost * Double(tip) / 100.0
var totalCost = mealCost + tipCost

print(totalCost)
```
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Explanation']

First we'll calculate how much the tip will cost. We use the same approach as `Problem 3.2` to get a percentage using multiplication. Keep in mind that we have to conver the tip to type `Double`, multiplying a variable of type `Int` with a variable of type `Double` is not allowed.

[/spoiler]

exercises.content:
### 3.4 Rounding

You are given a variable `number` of type `Double`. Create a new variable called `roundedNumber` that has at most `1` digit after the decimal dot.

```swift
var number = 5.1517
// your code here
```

[spoiler title="Example 1" collapse_link="true"]  
Input:
```swift
var number = 5.1517
```

Expected values:
```swift
roundedNumber = 5.1
```
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title="Example 2" collapse_link="true"]  
Input:
```swift
var number = 32.5
```

Expected values:
```swift
roundedNumber = 32.5
```
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title="Example 3" collapse_link="true"]  
Input:
```swift
var number = 2.0
```

Expected values:
```swift
roundedNumber = 2.0
```
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Hint' collapse_link='true']  
Converting a `Double` to an `Int` discards all the digits after the decimal point.    
[/spoiler]  

[spoiler title='Solution' collapse_link='true']
```swift
var number = 5.1517

var intNumber = Int(number * 10.0)

var roundedNumber = Double(intNumber) / 10.0

```
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Explanation']

Converting a `Double` to an `Int` will discard all the digits after the decimal point we want to keep a digit tough so we'll multiply the number by `10` first then we'll discard all the digits by converting to `Int`, finally we'll convert back to `Double` and divide by `10` to shift the decimal point to the right.

[/spoiler]

exercises.content:
### 3.5 Above average

You are given three grades obtained by 3 students in a class stored in variables `grade1`, `grade2`, `grade3` of type `Double`.   
You are also given your grade in the class stored in a variable `yourGrade` of type `Double`.   
Print `above average` if your grade is greater than the class average or `below average`" otherwise.  
**Note:** the average of the class includes your grade.

```swift
var grade1 = 7.0
var grade2 = 9.0
var grade3 = 5.0
var yourGrade = 8.0

// your code here
```

[spoiler title="Example 1" collapse_link="true"]  
Input:
```swift
var grade1 = 7.0
var grade2 = 9.0
var grade3 = 5.0
var yourGrade = 8.0
```

Output:
```
"above average"
```
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title="Example 2" collapse_link="true"]  
Input:
```swift
var grade1 = 10.0
var grade2 = 9.0
var grade3 = 10.0
var yourGrade = 9.0
```

Output:
```
"below average"
```
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Hint' collapse_link='true']  
Compare the average with your grade.
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Solution' collapse_link='true']
```swift
var grade1 = 7.0
var grade2 = 9.0
var grade3 = 5.0
var yourGrade = 8.0

var averageGrade = (grade1 + grade2 + grade3 + yourGrade) / 4.0

if yourGrade > averageGrade {
	print("above average")
} else {
	print("below average")
}

```
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Explanation']

First we'll calculate the `averageGrade` of the class. Then we are goind to determine if you are above or below that grade. 

[/spoiler]

exercises.content:
### 3.6 Fields

A farmer is harvesting wheat from a number of wheat fields, given in a variable `numberOfFields` of type `Int`.  
Each field produces the same quantity of wheat given in a variable `wheatYield` of type `Double`.  
Sometimes the harvest is increased by `50%` due to favorable weather conditions. You are given this information in a variable `weatherWasGood` of type `Bool`.  
Print the total amount of wheat that the farmer will harvest.  

```swift
var numberOfFields:Int = 5
var wheatYield:Double = 7.5
var weatherWasGood:Bool = true

// your code here
```

[spoiler title="Example 1" collapse_link="true"]  
Input:
```swift
var numberOfFields:Int = 5
var wheatYield:Double = 7.5
var weatherWasGood:Bool = true
```

Output:
```
56.25
```
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title="Example 2" collapse_link="true"]  
Input:
```swift
var numberOfFields:Int = 5
var wheatYield:Double = 7.5
var weatherWasGood:Bool = false
```

Output:
```
37.5
```
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Solution' collapse_link='true']
```swift
var numberOfFields:Int = 5
var wheatYield:Double = 7.5
var weatherWasGood:Bool = true

var totalYield = Double(numberOfFields) * wheatYield
if (weatherWasGood == true) {
    totalYield = totalYield * 1.5
}

print(totalYield)
```
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Explanation']

The total yield is given by `numberOfField * wheatYield`, keep in mind that you'll have to convert `numberOfFields` to `Double` as its an `Int`. Finally We want to multiply the yield by `1.5` if the year was good.

[/spoiler]

```swift
if (weatherWasGood == true) {
    totalYield = totalYield * 1.5
}

print(totalYield)
```
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Explanation']

The total yield is given by `numberOfField * wheatYield`, keep in mind that you'll have to convert `numberOfFields` to `Double` as its an `Int`. Finally We want to multiply the yield by `1.5` if the year was good.

[/spoiler]

### 3.6 Fields

A farmer is harvesting wheat from a number of wheat fields, given in a variable `numberOfFields` of type `Int`.  
Each field produces the same quantity of wheat given in a variable `wheatYield` of type `Double`.  
Sometimes the harvest is increased by `50%` due to favorable weather conditions. You are given this information in a variable `weatherWasGood` of type `Bool`.  
Print the total amount of wheat that the farmer will harvest.

content:
## 4. Loops

#### Introduction

Let's make make some pancakes!

![](https://www.weheartswift.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/pancakes.jpg)

So far we only looked at programs that have a fixed number of steps. For example look the *algorithm* to make a pancake:

```
- put 1/4 cup of batter in the frying pan
- cook for about 2 minutes
- flip and cook for another 2 minutes
- remove the pancake
```

How would the algorithm to make 10 pancakes would look? Would it be much different?

```
10 times do:
	- put 1/4 cup of batter in the frying pan
	- cook for about 2 minutes
	- flip and cook for another 2 minutes
	- remove the pancake
```

Loops let you describe repetitive processes. They could have a fixed amount of steps like the example above. Or they could have an unknow number of steps, for example a more realistic algorithm for making pancakes:

```
while you have pancake batter do:
	- put 1/4 cup of batter in the frying pan
	- cook for about 2 minutes
	- flip and cook for another 2 minutes
	- remove the pancake
```
#### `while` 

A `while` loop performs a set of statements until a condition becomes `false`.  

**while** `condition` {  
    `statements`  
}

For example in order to `print` all the numbers from 1 to 10. We need to create a variable with the initial value of 1. Print the value and increase it by one and until it becomes bigger than 10.

```swift
var i = 1
while i <= 10 {
    print(i)
    i = i + 1
}
```

#### `repeat`

`repeat` loops while a condition is met. The difference between a `while` and a `repeat` loop is that the repeat loop evaluates the condition after executing the statements from the loop.

**repeat** {  
    `statements`  
} **while** `condition`

```swift
var i = 1
repeat {
    print(i)
    i = i + 1
} while i < 10
```

Both `while` and `repeat` are best used in loops where the numbers of stepts is unkown. Take for example the algorithm of converting a number to binary: divide the number by two until it becomes 0. Write the reminders from right to left to get the binary form of the number.

```swift
var number = 123

var binary = 0
var digit  = 1


while number > 0 {
    let reminder = number % 2
    
    // add the new digit to the number
    binary = digit * reminder + binary
    
    // move the digit to the left
    digit *= 10

    // remove the last binary digit
    number /= 2
}

binary // 1111011
```


#### `for` loops

Swift provides two kinds of loops that perform a set of statements a certain number of times:

The **for-in** loop performs a set of statements for each item in a range or collection.

Swift also provides two range operators `a..<b` and `a...b`, as a shortcut for expressing a range of values.

```swift
1...3 // 1, 2, 3
1..<3 // 1, 2
```

**for** `value` **in** `range` {  
    `statements`      
}

```swift
// prints 1-10
for i in 1...10 {
    print(i)
}

// prints 0-9
for i in 0..<10 {
    print(i)
}
```

The **for** loop performs a set of statements until a specific condition is met, typically by incrementing a counter each time the loop ends.

**for** `initialization`; `condition`; `increment` {  
    `statements`  
}

```swift 
// ++i is shorthand for i = i + 1
// prints 1-10
for var i = 1; i <= 10; ++i {
    print(i)
}

// prints 10-1 
for var i = 10; i > 0; --i {
    print(i)
}
```

#### `print` and terminators

For the drawing exercises below you will need use the `terminator` parameter for the `print` function. The `terminator` refers to the thing that is printed at the end. The default terminator is the new line character `"\n"`. 
- `print(value)` will print the value and a new line
- `print(value, terminator: "")` will print the value


```swift
print("BAT", terminator: "") // prints BAT
print("MAN", terminator: "") // prints MAN
print("") // prints a newline character
// BATMAN

print("BAT")
// BAT
print("MAN")
// MAN
```

#### Executing a statement multiple times

Sometimes you just want to execute some statements multiple times but don't care about having an index. A swift convention in `for` loops is to use `_` as the loop variable name when you don't intend to use the variable in the loop.

For examplet to to print "Hello World" 5 times you can use:
```swift
for _ in 1...5 {
	print("Hello World")
}
```

Naming your loop variable `_` is useful because you immediately tell that the variable is not used in the loop.

exercises.content:
### 4.1 Chalkboard

Write a program that writes "I will not skip the fundamentals!" `N` times. 

```swift
var N = 10

// your code here
```

[spoiler title='Example 1' collapse_link='true']  
Input:
```swift
var N = 3
```

Output:
```
I will not skip the fundamentals!
I will not skip the fundamentals!
I will not skip the fundamentals!
```
[/spoiler]


[spoiler title='Example 2' collapse_link='true']  
Input:
```swift
var N = 5
```

Output:
```
I will not skip the fundamentals!
I will not skip the fundamentals!
I will not skip the fundamentals!
I will not skip the fundamentals!
I will not skip the fundamentals!
```
[/spoiler]


[spoiler title='Hint' collapse_link='true']  
The solution to a similar problem was shown in the theory, you can use either `for` or `while` to solve this problem.
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Solution 1' collapse_link='true']
```swift
var N = 10

// with a while loop
var times = 0
while times < N {
    print("I will not skip the fundamentals!")
    times = times + 1
}
```
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Solution 2' collapse_link='true']
```swift
var N = 10
// with a for loop
for _ in 1...N {
    print("I will not skip the fundamentals!")
}
```
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Explanation']

We'll want to print the statement "I will not skip the fundamentals" in a loop `N` times, we can use a `for` or a `while` loop for this.

[/spoiler]

exercises.content:
### 4.2 Squares

Print the first `N` square numbers. A square number, also called perfect square, is an integer that is obtained by squaring some other integer; in other words, it is the product of some integer with itself (ex. `1`, `4` = `2` * `2`, `9` = `3` * `3` ...).

```swift 
var N = 10

// your code here
```

[spoiler title='Example 1' collapse_link='true']  
Input:
```swift
var N = 2
```

Output:
```
1
4
```
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Example 2' collapse_link='true']  
Input:
```swift
var N = 5
```

Output:
```
1
4
9
16
25
```
[/spoiler]


[spoiler title='Solution' collapse_link='true']
```swift
var N = 10

var cnt = 1

while cnt <= N {
    print(cnt * cnt)

    cnt = cnt + 1
}
```
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Explanation']

We'll want to iterate from `1` to `N` in a loop. In the solution `cnt` is our loop index(also called `counter`). The square number we want to print for each index is `cnt * cnt`.

[/spoiler]

exercises.content:
### 4.3 Powers of 2

Print the powers of `2` that are less than or equal to `N`. 

```swift 
var N = 10

// your code here
```

[spoiler title='Example 1' collapse_link='true']  
Input:
```swift
var N = 5
```

Output:
```
2
4
```
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Example 2' collapse_link='true']  
Input:
```swift
var N = 100
```

Output:
```
2
4
8
16
32
64
```
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Hint' collapse_link='true']  
The first power of `2`  is `2`. Given a power of `2`, `power`, the next power of `2` is `power * 2`.
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Solution' collapse_link='true']
```swift
var N = 10

var power = 2

while power <= N {
    print(power)
    power = power * 2
}
```
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Explanation']

We'll want to intialize a loop variable `power` to 2. We'll repeat a `while` loop in which we print `power` and double its value while `power <= N`. This will print all the powers of 2 less then or equal to `N`.

[/spoiler]

exercises.content:
### 4.4 Alternative Counting

Write all the numbers from 1 to `N` in alternative order, one number from the left side (starting with one) and one number from the right side (starting from `N` down to `1`).

```swift
var N = 5

// your code here
```

[spoiler title='Example 1' collapse_link='true']  
Input:
```swift
var N = 4
```

Output:
```
1
4
2
3
```
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Example 2' collapse_link='true']  
Input:
```swift
var N = 9
```

Output:
```
1
9
2
8
3
7
4
6
5
```
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Hint 1' collapse_link='true']
Use two variables to remember the `left` and `right` index that you need to print next. 
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Hint 2' collapse_link='true']
There's a special case you'll have to handle when `N` is odd.
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Solution' collapse_link='true']
```swift
var N = 5

var left = 1
var right = N

while left < right {
    print(left)
    print(right)
    ++left
    --right
}

if left == right {
    print(left)
}
```
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Explanation']

We'l use a `while` loop where we simultaneously increase a variable `left`, initialised to `1` and decrease a variable `right`, initialized to `N`. We repeat these steps until `left becomes greater than or equal to right`. We'll also have to handle the case when `left` becomes equal to `right` once our loop has finished, this will only happen for odd `N`.

[/spoiler]

exercises.content:
### 4.5 Square

Given an integer `N` draw a square of `N x N` asterisks. Look at the examples.

```swift
var N = 4

// your code here
```

[spoiler title='Example 1' collapse_link='true']  
Input:
```swift
var N = 1
```

Output:
```
*
```
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Example 2' collapse_link='true']  
Input:
```swift
var N = 2
```

Output:
```
**
**
```
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Example 3' collapse_link='true']  
Input:
```swift
var N = 3
```

Output:
```
***
***
***
```
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Hint 1' collapse_link='true']
Try printing a single line of `*` first.
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Hint 2' collapse_link='true']
You can use `print("")` to print an empty line.
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Solution' collapse_link='true']
```swift
var N = 4

for i in 1...N {
    for j in 1...N {
        print("*", terminator: "")
    }
    print("")
}
```
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Explanation']

First consider the problem of printing a single line of `N` asterisks. we can do this using a for loop that makes `N` calls to the `print("*", terminator: "")` statement. After printing a line of asterisks we want to print a new line. Remember that this is done via the `print("")` statement. Now we want to repeat our loop for printing a line of asterisks in another for loop. This gives us 2 nested loops that solve our problem.

[/spoiler]

### 4.7 Triangle

Given an integer `N` draw a triangle of asterisks. The triangle should have `N` lines, the `i`-th line should have `i` asterisks on it. 

```swift
var N = 4

// your code here
```


[spoiler title='Example 1' collapse_link='true']  
Input:
```swift
var N = 1
```

Output:
```
*
```
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Example 2' collapse_link='true']  
Input:
```swift
var N = 3
```

Output:
```
*
**
***
```
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Example 3' collapse_link='true']  
Input:
```swift
var N = 4
```

Output:
```
*
**
***
****
```
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Hint' collapse_link='true']
First you'll want to print a single `*`. Then you'll want to print 2 `*`, then 3 `*`. How many stars will you print at the `i-th` iteration?
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Solution' collapse_link='true']
```swift
var N = 3

for i in 1...N {
    for j in 1...i {
        print("*", terminator: "")
    }
    print("")
}
```
[/spoiler]

[spoiler title='Explanation']

Again we'll want to use 2 nested loops. Our inner loop won't go from 1 to a fixed value now. Instead it will go from 1 to the value of the index in the inner loop such that we progressively print more asterisks per line.

[/spoiler]
